factoid: You have earned the St. George’s standards.
You will be worthy of the St. George’s standards.
Rostóv thought that he should die for the Tsar.
The Tsar said something more.
Rostóv did not hear the Tsar's words.
The soldiers shouted 'Hurrah!' while straining their lungs.
Rostóv shouted 'Hurrah!' with all his might.
Rostóv wanted to express his rapture fully by shouting 'Hurrah!' even if it might injure him.
The Tsar stopped a few minutes in front of the hussars as if undecided.
Rostóv thought that the Emperor could not be undecided.
Rostóv found the Emperor's indecision majestic and enchanting, like everything else the Tsar did.
The hesitation lasted only an instant.
The Tsar's foot touched the groin of the bobtailed bay mare he rode.
The Tsar's hand in a white glove gathered up the reins.
The Tsar moved off accompanied by an irregularly swaying sea of aides-de-camp.
The Tsar rode farther and farther away.
The Tsar stopped at other regiments.
The Tsar's white plumes were visible to Rostóv from amid the suites that surrounded the Emperors.
Rostóv noticed Bolkónski among the gentlemen of the suite.
Bolkónski was sitting on his horse indolently and carelessly.
Rostóv recalled their quarrel of yesterday.
Rostóv wondered whether he ought to challenge Bolkónski.
Rostóv thought 'Of course not!'.
Rostóv questioned whether it was worth thinking or speaking of the challenge at that moment.
Rostóv believed that at a time of love, rapture, and self-sacrifice, quarrels and affronts do not matter.
Rostóv loved and forgave everybody now.
The Emperor passed nearly all the regiments.
The troops began a ceremonial march past the Emperor.
Rostóv rode past the Emperor on Bedouin, a horse recently purchased from Denísov.
Rostóv rode at the rear of his squadron, alone and in full view of the Emperor.
Rostóv was a splendid horseman.
Rostóv spurred Bedouin twice before reaching the Emperor.
Rostóv successfully put Bedouin into a showy trot when the animal was excited.
Bedouin bent his foaming muzzle to his chest.
Bedouin's tail was extended.
Bedouin passed splendidly, lifting his feet with a high and graceful action.
Bedouin appeared to fly through the air without touching the ground.
Rostóv rode past the Emperor with a frowning but blissful face.
Rostóv's face was like a very devil.
Rostóv felt one with his horse.
Rostóv's legs were well back and his stomach drawn in.
The Emperor remarked 'Fine fellows, the Pávlograds!'
Rostóv thought that he would be happy if the Emperor ordered him to leap into the fire instantly.
When the review was over, the newly arrived officers and Kutúzov’s officers collected in groups.
They began to talk about the awards.
They talked about the Austrians and their uniforms.
They talked about their lines.
They talked about Bonaparte.
They discussed how badly Bonaparte would fare if the Essen corps arrived and Prussia took their side.
The talk in every group was chiefly about Emperor Alexander.
Everyone described Emperor Alexander's every word and movement with ecstasy.
They all wished to advance as soon as possible against the enemy under the Emperor's command.
They were commanded by the Emperor himself.
They believed they could not fail to vanquish anyone.
Rostóv and most of the officers thought this after the review.
All were more confident of victory than winning two battles would have made them.
The day after the review, Borís rode to Olmütz to see Bolkónski.
Borís was in his best uniform.
Borís had Berg's best wishes for success.
Borís wished to profit from Bolkónski's friendliness.
Borís wanted to obtain the best post he could, preferably that of adjutant to an important personage.
Borís believed that position was the most attractive in the army.
Rostóv's father sends him ten thousand rubles at a time.
Rostóv can talk about not wishing to cringe to anybody and not be anyone's lackey.
Borís reflected that it is all very well for Rostóv to talk about not wishing to cringe to anybody and not be anyone's lackey.
Borís reflected that he has nothing but his brains.
Borís reflected that he must make a career and must not miss opportunities.
Borís reflected that he must avail himself of opportunities.
Borís did not find Prince Andrew in Olmütz that day.
The town had the headquarters and the diplomatic corps stationed there.
The two Emperors lived with their suites, households, and courts in the town.
The appearance of the town strengthened Borís's desire to belong to that higher world.
